newsitem.title: EL SALVADOR: El Salvador sugar harvest seen at 340,000 tonnes.
newsitem.headline: El Salvador sugar harvest seen at 340,000 tonnes.

text.p: Thousands of El Salvador workers on Monday began harvesting the nation's sugar crop, expected to total 340,000 tonnes and draw $141 million, according to Sugar Association estimates.
The 1996-1997 harvest is expected to produce 20,000 tonnes more sugar than last year's crop, association director Mario Salaverria said.
Income from sugar sales are expected to rise by $11.5 million compared to the 1995-1996 crop, he added.
Agriculture Minister Ricardo Quinonez marked the start of the sugar and coffee harvests in a ceremony 19 miles (30 km) west of San Salvador.
Some 33,000 workers between December and March will be working to harvest this year's sugar crop.
This year's harvest features a security plan, with thousands of soldiers patrolling the fields.
Salaverria said the program is part of an effort to avoid robberies that have become common at harvest time.
